column1: Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Gen AI Assistant","This article will walk you through the features and functionality of the Gen AI Assistant within Rentvine. ","en","https://help.rentvine.com/gen-ai-assistant","
<li>To access the Gen AI assistant within your Rentvine account you can click on the Gen AI Icon in the top right-hand corner of your screen.&nbsp

<li>This will pull up the assistant where you will be able to type in your command and have the system create said command for you. You will be able to select from the list below for commands the assistant can complete.
• Add Bill- Create a bill for [vendor] for [amount] due [date].

column2: Create a Lease Charge for [amount] for [tenant] for [description].

column1: • Record Tenant Receipt- Record a payment of [amount] from [tenant].
• Record Owner Receipt- Record a contribution of [amount] from [owner].
• Add Tenant Credit- Add a credit of [amount] to [address].

<li>You can also use a text-to-speech option by clicking the microphone icon. You will then have to allow Rentvine to access your microphone. Once complete you will be able to speak your command to the system.&nbsp

<li>You will see when the microphone is in use based on the red highlight around the microphone icon. When you are finished speaking you can click the microphone icon again and it will read your command.&nbsp

column2: ><strong>Please note that the text-to-speech option is also available within the Global Search but will not complete Gen AI commands.&nbsp

column1: <li>Walking through an example request for a new lease charge you can see that the lease charge command is entered, and the tenant's name, description, and the amount are filled in this field. To process this command submit must be selected.&nbsp

<li>You will see that this processes the request and will take you to the lease charge page for the selected tenant and will prefill all of the information. All that will need to be done is a quick review and confirm the selection by clicking save.&nbsp

column2: ><strong>Please note that this will be the same process and workflow for the other commands, just changing the command type from the list.&nbsp

column1: Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Webinar on Owner Statements","This webinar reviews the Owner Statements feature within Rentvine.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/owner-statements-webinar","{% video_player ""embed_player"" overrideable=False, type='hsvideo2', hide_playlist=True, viral_sharing=False, embed_button=False, autoplay=False, hidden_controls=False, loop=False, muted=False, full_width=False, width='688', height='476', player_id='188353326911', style='' %}

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Why Do I See System Created Owner Credits?","This article will show why and how the system prompts you to create a credit towards an owner.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/why-do-i-see-system-created-owner-credits","<ul>
<li>When you navigate the Rentvine software, you may notice there are some credits that were not created by a user, but instead created by the&nbsp

• The reason this typically occurs is when a management fee / suppressed fee is paid as normal by the tenant and is billed to the owner and paid out to the management company. At a later date, the tenant payment that funded the management fee was either voided/returned, meaning the property management company was paid out for a charge that is no longer paid. This causes the system to prompt you to create a credit to compensate the owner for the bill they paid for the management fee since it is no longer paid.

<li>Another reason this could occur is if a management fee / suppressed fee is paid as normal by the tenant and billed to the owner and paid out to the management company, but at a later date the&nbsp
• Here you can see an example of how this may have happened. In this example, the management fee (Late Fee) was paid by the tenant and the management company billed this out as normal.
column2: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-08%20at%2011-50-17%E2%80%AFAM-png-1.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
column3: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-08%20at%2012-58-40%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • If for any reason the tenant's payment is returned due to things such as NSF, incorrect card numbers, etc. It will show on the lease as returned and you may see the charge as unpaid now. This occurs after the management fee is already paid by the owner.

<li>Now that the original payment was returned, this means the owner was billed for a charge that no longer shows as paid in the system. Next time the property management company goes through the billing process, they will see a credit amount due to the owner now.&nbsp
<li>Once this is created, you will see the credit under the&nbsp

column2:
src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-08%20at%201-58-13%E2%80%AFPM-png-1.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

You can confirm this is a system-created credit by clicking the credit and scrolling towards the bottom to view the Timeline of the credit. Here it will show the User who created the credit and a brief description as to why it was created.

column1: Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Portfolio Global Settings","This article will go over the portfolio settings, including how to Enable Balance Notices, how to Exclude Reserves when Calculating Total Required Reserves, how to set a Balance Notice Threshold, and Email Template For Balance Notices.
• To get started, click your initials at the top right
column6: and here you can see the Portfolio Settings
column8: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-26%20at%202-48-10%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
column10: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-26%20at%202-48-18%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column4: >Enable Balance Notices - Having this on will notify the owner whenever the balance falls below the threshold set in the portfolio settings
column8: >Exclude Reserves When Calculating Total Required Reserves-
column9: If you exclude reserves, Rentvine will not count the reserve balances when determining how much money should be in the trust account. This is useful if you manage reserves separately or don’t want them affecting your trust compliance calculations.
column12: >Balance Notice Threshold- The Balance Notice Threshold is a setting in Rentvine that helps you monitor low balances in your owners’ or properties’ accounts. It controls when Rentvine will alert you that an account balance has dropped below a certain amount.
column15: >Email Template For Balance Notices- In Rentvine, you can automate low balance warnings using Balance Notice Email Templates. These emails notify owners, property managers, or internal team members when an account balance falls below a set threshold, helping you manage funds proactively.

column2: data-start=""182"" data-end=""441"">You can create and adjust these templates by going to your&nbsp
column5: Email Templates. From that setting, you can create a template to associate with your balance notice to ensure consistent communication for all users in your Software.

column2: data-start=""182"" data-end=""441"">For more information about email template creation see our article on adding and creating email templates here:How to Add/Create Email Templates

column1: • Application Provider - This will be the provider you choose to use for running your applications, whether it is Rentvine directly or a third-party service that has been integrated with the Rentvine platform.
• If Rentvine is selected, then you will be presented with more options to adjust
• If Other is selected, you will be given an option to input a default application link

column2: This option should be selected if you would like your applications to be enabled and available for users
This setting allows applicants to submit an application without selecting a specific property address. Toggling this on will present more option for adjusting the Generic Application

This means that the applicant can create a blank application, but it will only allow the applicant to choose units currently available. Toggling this off allows applicants to enter any address they type within the application
This allows you to select a specific application template to use for the Generic Applications instead of the Default Application Template

column1: • Auto Assign Application to Assignee of Property -
column2: This setting will automatically assign the application to the current assignee designated at the property level.

column1: <li>This screen will show you all the application templates you have currently in the system, and whether they are active or not.&nbsp

column1: • This screen will show all Addendum Templates that have been created on your account. To create a new Addendum Template, you can follow this article: 🔗 Creating a New Addendum Template

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Add a Cosigner to a Lease","Do you have a cosigner that you need associated with a lease and but do not want to add them as a regular tenant contact? This article will walk you through setting up cosigners.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-add-a-co-signer","

To start, you can add the cosigner within the move-in flow. To start this navigate to the leases tab, click the green actions button, and click create lease.

In the tenants section of the move-in, you will be able to add a cosigner under the ""Cosigners"" section. Here you can add a new cosigner or add an existing tenant as a cosigner, just like you can with tenant contacts. This will still create the user as a tenant contact but will be assigned differently as a cosigner at the lease level.
Within an already created lease, you will be able to view this within the tenant section. From here, you can click the blue actions and select either Add Existing Tenant or Add New Tenant.
column4:
src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-22%20at%203-38-25%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">


On the next screen, you will be given the option to mark this new tenant contact as a

column1: Once the contact has been created, you will now see a new section labeled Cosigners.

You can also create this field directly from an application if the cosigner selects this option under the I am the ... field

column1: To have this field available, please ensure to check your application template and that the
column2: I Am The... field is set to
column5:

For more information on how to adjust the application template, please review this article: How to Edit an Application Template

column1: When you create a lease directly from the application, it will automatically create this Cosigner contact during the lease creation process.

column1: For a step-by-step guide on how to create a lease from the application directly, please follow this article: Creating a lease from an application directly
This also allows you to release the Cosigners
column2: if needed once the lease is being closed out. To do this, click the 3 dots next to the Cosigner in question and select Release Cosigner. Doing this will allow you to adjust the end date, signifying when the release occurred, and you can also revoke their portal access if needed. Once saved, this will create a new section labeled Past Cosigners.

column1: Releasing the Cosigner will automatically disable their Recurring Payment

column3: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-22%20at%203-50-23%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
column6: reinstate a cosigner if needed once they have been released. To do this, click the 3 dots next to the Past Cosigner in question and select Reinstate.
column9: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-22%20at%203-56-56%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
column11: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-04-22%20at%203-57-15%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • Co-signers can now be included in email and text campaigns, but are clearly separated from tenants in mass communications.
• Lease chat functionality now supports direct communication with Co-Signers.
• Can I use Co-Signers within Rentsign and in letter/email templates?
• Email and letter templates now include separate hot fields for Co-Signers.
• Co-Signer Names is a new hot field added to the lease Rentsign documents.
• The Co-Signer is now an added party role to select from in addition to the owner and tenant party roles.
<li data-stringify-indent=""1"" data-stringify-border=""0"">How can I search for Co-Signers?
• Global search has been updated to better distinguish between tenants and Co-Signers.
<li data-stringify-indent=""1"" data-stringify-border=""0"">Are co-signers excluded from anything?&nbsp
• Co-Signers are excluded from work orders to ensure only residents receive service-related communication.
• They are no longer included in RUBS (Ratio Utility Billing System) allocations.
• Co-Signers are excluded from refund options during the move-out process to prevent processing errors.

column1: Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Collect a Lease Fee","Did you create a new lease and want to charge the owner a lease fee? This article shows you how to collect a lease fee that is billed to the owner.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-collect-a-lease-fee","<ol>
• Navigate to the current lease you want to collect the fee for.
• In the lease search box, search for the address or tenant(s)
• Click on the lease when you have found the correct lease
• Once in the Lease, scroll down until you get to the Lease Fee card section. Select Collect Lease Fee.
<li>When collecting lease fees, Rentvine will automatically calculate the lease fee based on the settings set on the management fee profile.&nbsp
column2: You are able to edit the amount here. When you are content with the amount, choose <strong>Collect.&nbsp
column3: *Note the Date Posted will be the date the lease fee will be charged/billed.
column4: Once done, this will automatically create a bill to the owner to be paid to the property management company.

column1: • How often does a notification get sent to the landowner?
• The landlord will get an email notification every 24 hours for the next 72 hours. Once the 72 hours have passed, the notifications will cease.
• Can I send the landlord verification out again?
• After the initial 72 hours, you cannot continue to send an email notification to the landlord to complete the verification form.
• Can you edit the landlord questionnaire sent to them?
• At this time, you cannot edit the landlord verification questionnaire that is sent to these landlords.
• Can we see when the email notifications are sent to the landlords?

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"RVA - Reviewing Payments going out of Rentvine","This week, we will review the key details to watch for in Rentvine to help you and your team become familiar with the payment recording process and learn how to identify important information for any payment entered into the system.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/rva-understand-payments","<hr>

{% video_player ""embed_player"" overrideable=False, type='hsvideo2', hide_playlist=True, viral_sharing=False, embed_button=False, autoplay=False, hidden_controls=False, loop=False, muted=False, full_width=False, width='688', height='387', player_id='191059566391', style='' %}

• When making a payment in Rentvine, you can select 1 of 4 options: Check, eCheck (ACH), NACHA (ACH), or Other. This week will guide you in looking for details in the different types of payments and looking for information regarding the payment.
column3:
src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%203-09-48%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

You can view which bank account the specific payment comes out of under the Bank Account section
column5:
src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%203-10-57%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

You can find the payment type (Check, eCheck, NACHA, or Other) under the Payment Type section of the individual transaction.
column7:
src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%203-12-01%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

You can also find a history of anything that may have been adjusted on the payment using the Timeline of the payment located at the bottom of the page for the transaction.

column1: • Selecting Check within Rentvine typically means that this payment will be printed using the Check Template associated with the bank account.
column2: Rentvine will give you the option to print this check out through the system.&nbsp
has been printed through Rentvine, you will see a

column1: • You can also still adjust the posted date, the memo, or the check number if needed by clicking the green actions button.

column1: <li>If the check bounces for any reason and is returned, you can properly record that as well using the&nbsp

Remote Checks enabled, you will see an additional option to send Remote Checks via LOB. To enable remote checks, please reach out to support@rentvine.com

This article goes over the Remote Checks feature as well. Using the Remote Check Feature
column6:
name=Screenshot%202024-05-30%20at%2010-10-00%20AM-png.png"" width=""206"" loading=""lazy"">

Once sent, you will see the Check Image in the Remote Checks section of the payment:

column1: • Selecting eCheck (ACH) means this payment will be sent electronically. Once these payments are initiated and approved, the funds will be sent immediately to the recipient's account. Once processed, these ACH payments cannot be voided or stopped. There will be a one-dollar charge added to your monthly invoice for every outgoing payment.
<li>Once the payment is sent, you will see the exact transaction number tied to the transaction under the&nbsp
column3: This is a good way to know if something was processed through our payment processor.

column1: • For eCheck payment, you can still adjust the date posted if needed by clicking the green actions button and selecting edit.
<li>If a payment bounces and fails, Rentvine automatically records this for you in the software
column2: you do not need to manually record the return like you would with a Check payment.

column1: <li>You can see at the top right of the payment if it has fully settled or not. You can view the exact settlement of an electronic payment once it has fully settled in the system.&nbsp
column4: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%204-26-08%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column2:
NACHA (ACH) is selected, the payment can be sent electronically through your bank portal. This means you will need to download the NACHA File in Rentvine for the payment. There will not be any charge for outgoing payments.
The NACHA download button can be found in the
column3: Payment Batch of the payment.
column4: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%2011-30-04%E2%80%AFAM-png.png"" width=""3294"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: <li>If the NACHA payment bounces for any reason and is returned, you can properly record that as well using the <strong>Return&nbsp

• Although this is an ACH payment, you can still void the payment after it has been approved. Unlike an eCheck payment, these funds are not distributed until the NACHA file is uploaded to your bank portal.

To set up NACHA, please follow this article on how to do this: Enabling NACHA Payments for a Bank Account

For testing if NACHA is correctly set up, follow this article: Testing a NACHA File

column2: Other signifies that this type of payment is occurring
column4: of the system and is recorded in Rentvine for accounting purposes. No funds are actually being moved through the Rentvine Software. Using other allows you to select how these funds were transferred in the real world, either being a credit card payment, bank transfer, etc.

column2: Other Payment even after it has been recorded in Rentvine by clicking the green actions button and selecting
column4: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%2012-59-07%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""3294"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • These payments are meant to record a transaction that has occurred or will occur in the real world, not being initiated through Rentvine.
• Can we void payments after they have been created in Rentvine?
• You can void any type of payment as long as they are not
• Can we print the checks multiple times if needed?
• Yes, you can reprint any check and adjust the dates on the check if needed
• Can we adjust the payment type after it has already been created in the system, for example check to eCheck?
• To do this, you will need to void the original payment and recreate the payment again using the correct payment type. Please keep in mind, if the original payment was an eCheck, you cannot void it.
What happens if a payment fails or is returned?
For Check and NACHA payments, use the Return option to record the failed payment.
For eCheck (ACH) payments, Rentvine will automatically record the return for you

column2: What is the difference between eCheck and NACHA payments?

column1: • eCheck (ACH) payments are processed directly through Rentvine’s payment processor and are sent immediately.
NACHA payments require you to download a file from Rentvine and manually upload it to your bank portal.

column2: Is there a fee for sending eChecks?

column1: Yes, there is a $1 fee added to your monthly invoice for each outgoing eCheck (ACH) payment.
<li>Remote check is a check sent in the mail on your part through our remote check processor. There is a one-dollar fee added to your monthly invoice for every check sent.&nbsp

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Enable Reporting within the Owner Portal","Would you like all of your owners to be able to view reports within their owner portal? This article will walk you through enabling this and how this looks for the owner. ","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-enable-reporting-within-the-owner-portal","<ul>
• To enable this, you will need to click on your initials in the top right-hand corner. From this dropdown, you can click on ""Settings"" to access the global settings.
• In here, navigate to the ""Portals"" section and click on the ""Owner Settings"" option.
<li>Click the ""Manage Settings"" in the top right of this box. From here, set the ""Is Reporting Enabled"" dropdown to ""Yes"".&nbsp

column1: <li>Now, impersonating an owner portal, you will see that there is a section for reports. The reports below will be available for the owner to pull from their portal.
<li>This allows the owner to filter by certain objects and add columns just like on the admin portal.&nbsp

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"RVA - How to Correct Suppressed Fees after the Charge was Created","This week will show how to fix a suppressed fee after the original charge was created. This will fix any charges to become suppressed and adjust them accordingly. ","en","https://help.rentvine.com/rva-suppressed-charges","<hr>

{% video_player ""embed_player"" overrideable=False, type='hsvideo2', hide_playlist=True, viral_sharing=False, embed_button=False, autoplay=False, hidden_controls=False, loop=False, muted=False, full_width=False, width='688', height='445', player_id='191601931828', style='' %}
<li>The best way to confirm this is if you look at your&nbsp
column2: Management Fee Setting for a specific property, a lease is tied to, and view if this is suppressed or not. If the
column4: was created first before the Chart of Account was added to the Management Fee Setting, then this article will be perfect for you on a guide to correct this mistake and how to properly add the Charge for future reference
column8: name=Screenshot%202024-06-10%20at%201-49-54%20PM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
column12: name=Screenshot%202024-06-10%20at%201-51-38%20PM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • To start, you will need to go to the lease where this situation occurred. You can then click on the transactions tab to view all of the charges and receipts associated with this lease.

• Click into the charge that is supposed to be suppressed but isn't. This needs to be reallocated because you can not edit a charge when there is a receipt allocated. If there is no receipt allocated to the charge, please skip to
• If you scroll down on the charge page, you will be able to see the receipt that allocated and paid this specific charge. Click on this allocated receipt.
column5: name=Screenshot%202024-06-10%20at%202-02-49%20PM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • If you scroll down again, you will see a ""Reapply"" button that you will click on. This will allow you to change the amount allocated and pay for certain charges.

• Since the charge that needs to be changed has a receipt allocated, we will need to zero out that amount. To do this, look for the charge and erase the current amount applied. You will then need to enter $0.00 in here and click the green ""Reapply"" button to save this.
column9: name=Screenshot%202024-06-10%20at%202-06-55%20PM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • Now that the charge does not have any receipt allocated to it, you can click on it to edit it. To do this, you will go back to the transactions tab of the lease and click on the charge that needs to be changed. You should now see that this has a banner under it labeled ""Amount Unpaid"" for the full amount of the charge.

column2: In here, you will need to click on the edit button in the charge details box. This will pull up a screen that will allow you to change different information. This is why the charge can not have any allocated receipt attached, because if it did, you would not be able to change most of this information.

column1: • You will need to edit the ""Account"". Please note that this will show the account as already being suppressed, but we will still need to make these changes to fully reset it. You will need to change this Account to any other chart of account (it does not matter which one, as we are going to switch it right back). Make sure to click save after this is done.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How To Fix Positive/Negative Receivable Balances After Transferring Property To The New Portfolio","This article addresses scenarios where a property is transferred into Rentvine, and over time, a negative receivables balance appears. This typically occurs due to discrepancies during the property transfer process.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/property-transfer-positvie/negatvie-recievables-blances-after-property-transfer","
column2: >Below, you’ll find a step-by-step guide to help you identify the cause and correct both positive and negative receivables balances resulting from the transfer using examples.

>In this scenario, the portfolio listed below reflects a positive receivables balance of $2,344.00, which signifies that there are unpaid charges tied to one or more leases associated with this portfolio. This typically occurs when a property is transferred and not all outstanding charges are addressed during the transition. It’s important to identify the lease or leases contributing to the balance, review their ledgers, and determine whether the charges are still valid or require adjustment. Once the appropriate actions are taken, such as voiding duplicate charges or reallocating payments, the receivables balance should update accordingly.

column1: • After selecting the Leases tab, it’s apparent that there are no active leases under this portfolio. This typically indicates that the property was transferred to a different portfolio. To determine the cause of the receivables balance, the next step is to locate the property in its new portfolio and review its lease ledger. This will help identify any charges that were not cleared during the transfer and are now contributing to the outstanding receivables balance.
You can view the portfolio ledger to review any transactions associated with the property, then cross-reference that same property within the Properties tab to confirm its current location.

• If you return to the portfolio ledger, you’ll notice that the property located at 4971 Bonita Bay Boulevard, Bonita Springs, FL, is no longer listed under the Properties tab, and the lease previously connected to it is also no longer associated with the Linton Portfolio. This indicates that the property was transferred to a different portfolio.
• You can also select the property hyperlink from the portfolio ledger, which will take you directly to that property’s profile for further review.

• From there, you can scroll down to the Portfolio Details section. Under the green “Change Portfolio” button, you’ll see a “Past Portfolio” listed, which indicates that this property was transferred from a previous portfolio.

• You can select the “Past Portfolio” option to view the portfolio the property was originally associated with. In the example below, the current portfolio is listed as “Dave 11,” while the past portfolio is shown as “Linton.” This indicates that the property originally belonged to the Linton portfolio and was later transferred to the Dave 11 portfolio while there were still unpaid charges associated with it.

• If you select the Dave 11 portfolio, you will notice a negative receivables balance. This indicates that the property had unpaid charges associated with the past portfolio, which were subsequently paid on the new portfolio.

column2: >How to Resolve Positive and Negative Receivables Balances

column1: • You will need to select the lease that’s connected to the property.
• Next, select the Transactions tab to view the charges that were added to that lease.

• From there, start by selecting a charge to view its audit log. This helps identify which charges were created on the previous portfolio before the transfer. Sometimes, you can quickly spot the charge if the amounts match. If the amounts differ or are spread across multiple units, you’ll need to review the audit log for each charge to determine which were created in the old portfolio for each unit or lease.
• Next, select the green action button, then choose Audit Log.
• Now that you are in the audit log for the charge, scroll down to the Accrual Transaction Entries section. This will display the ledger where the charge was created.
• By reviewing the Accrual Transaction Entries, you’ll notice that the charge was created on the Linton portfolio, while the property is currently assigned to the Dave 11 portfolio.

• Since this is a charge and not a payment, we can simply void the charge to zero out the receivables balance for both portfolios.
    Next, we can select the payment and reapply the funds from the charge so it shows as unpaid.
    You can go back to the allocated payment and select the payments allocated to that charge.
• Now that we are in the payment, we can select “Reapply” to zero out the funds from the charge. Once zeroed out, select “Reapply” again to save the changes.
• Go back to the charge that is now showing as unpaid, select the green action button, and then choose “Void” to remove the charge.
• Once voided, you will notice that both the new and past portfolios now have a zero receivables balance.
• If you still have a receivables balance due to current leases with unpaid charges, you can run a Lease Charges Report:
Filter the report by “Unpaid Only” to show leases with unpaid charges.
Cross-reference the balances in the report with the receivables balance on the portfolio.
Verify that the balances match and reflect current unpaid charges.
Optionally, filter the report by portfolio to view the total receivables balance for that portfolio.

• The final step is to recreate the charge on the lease, ensuring it is properly connected to the Dave 11 (new) portfolio. To do this, select the green action button on the lease and choose the “Add Charge” option. Enter the exact same details as the original charge that was voided. Once all information is accurately entered, click “Save” to finalize and apply the charge to the new portfolio. This ensures the financial records remain accurate and reflect the current portfolio structure.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Use Quick Actions","This article will go over all the options within the Quick Actions menu","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-use-quick-actions","

This article explains each quick action available when you click the rocket ship icon. This menu serves as a shortcut, allowing you to efficiently complete key tasks without having to navigate through multiple sections of the software.
Click on the rocket ship icon at the top of your Rentvine Account, located next to your initials.
• Selecting this option will automatically direct you to a page where you can create a new portfolio. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: Create a New Portfolio

• Selecting this option will take you directly to the property creation page, where you can enter all necessary details for the new property. Here, you’ll be able to assign the property to a portfolio, set reserve amounts, configure sales and withholding tax, and define management fee and maintenance settings. You can also specify a marketing showing provider as part of the setup.
column3: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-06-17%20at%209.44.37%20AM.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: • This option will automatically redirect you to the Move-In flow, which will create a new lease for a specific unit. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Create a Financial Lease (Move In)
• This option directs you to record a tenant receipt for a specific lease. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Record a Tenant Receipt
• This option directs you to record an owner receipt for a specific portfolio and owner. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Record an Owner Contribution/Receipt (Money In)
• This is an option to show a payment recorded outside of the Rentvine software.

• This option will automatically take you to a page where you can record a deposit specific to the bank account. This option is used to show that manually recorded receipts are deposited. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Record a Deposit
• This option provides a shortcut for automatically creating a charge for a specific lease. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Add a Charge to a Lease
• This option provides a shortcut for automatically posting late fees for a specific property. Here is an article you can follow to manually post late fees: How to Manually Post Late Fees
• This option directs you to a page where you can create a new bill. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Add, Edit, and Delete a Bill
• This option provides you with a shortcut to pay any outstanding bills within the specific bank account selected. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Pay Bills
• This option provides you with a shortcut to paying owners for a specific portfolio or all portfolios. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Pay Owners
• This option directs you to the New Bank Reconciliation page. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Complete a Bank Reconciliation
• This option provides you with a shortcut for creating a new work order for a property. For a further breakdown, please refer to this article: How to Add/Edit a Work Order
• This is a quick tool that can be used to calculate prorated rent for a specific rent amount.

column1: <li>The three options that you see via the drop-down are the Actual Days in a Month, a 30-Day Month, and Annual (actual days).
• How it works: Calculates rent based on the real number of days in the month (e.g., 28, 30, or 31 days depending on the calendar month).
How it works: Assumes every month has exactly 30 days, no matter which month it is.
• How it works: Calculates the daily rent based on 365 days in a year (or 366 for leap years), then multiplies by the number of days the tenant occupies the unit.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Create A Property","Need help creating a property or adding a newly acquired one?
This article will walk you through the steps to create and add a new property in the system.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-create-a-property","<ul>
• Step 1 - Head to the properties tab. Once there, select the green ""+ new property"" button in the top right corner.

column2: After selecting the green ""+ New Property"" button, that will bring you to the property creation screen. From there, you will add the Portfolio,
column3: <strong>Property Details, Accounting Settings, Marketing, Management, and Maintenance Settings.&nbsp

column2: >Select the portfolio that this property will belong to. This determines how the property is grouped for financial reporting, management, and accounting purposes within the system.

column6: > section, you’ll enter key information such as the property address
column12: >, and market rent amount

column1: Important: If the property is a multi-unit (e.g., duplex, triplex, apartment building), make sure to toggle on the ""Multi-Unit"" setting if you know you will be managing multiple units on this property. If this is not enabled at the time of creation, you will not be able to add individual units to the property later.
• Keep in mind that the information entered here will appear when the property is marketed, so it's important to ensure accuracy and completeness.

Property Types that can't be multi-unit include: Single Family Home and Mobile Home

Note: Once the property has been created, there will not be a way to change that toggle
• In the Accounting Settings section, you can configure key financial details for the property. This includes:
Reserve Amount – Set aside a minimum balance to be held in the property’s trust account.
Sales Tax Settings – Enable and configure applicable sales tax options.
Withholding Tax Agency – Specify the tax agency for any required withholding.
NSF Fee Amount – Define the fee to be charged for any returned (non-sufficient funds) payments.
These settings help ensure accurate accounting and compliance with financial regulations.
If you need a better understanding of sales tax, tax withholdings, and/or how to change the NSF fee amount, click on each article below.
- How to Configure and Post Tax Withholdings
- How to Edit the NSF Fee Amount of a Property or Unit

column2: >In the Marketing section, you have the option to connect a showing provider, such as Tenant Turner or ShowMojo, if you are using one. This allows for seamless scheduling and management of property showings directly through your integrated provider.

column1: • In the Management section, you can configure the management fee settings for this specific property or unit. This includes setting the fee type, percentage, or flat amount, and how it should be applied and paid out.
If you need further assistance on how to set up management fees, please see the article below.
- How to Set Up Management Fees Settings
In the Maintenance Settings section, you can configure optional property details, including:
Maintenance Limit – Set a dollar limit for maintenance approvals.
Year Built – Record the year the property was constructed.
Property Insurance Expiration Date – Track when the property’s insurance coverage expires.
Warranty Expiration Date – Enter the expiration date for any applicable property warranty.
These settings help streamline maintenance processes and keep important dates organized.
Once all the required information has been entered, click Save in the bottom-right corner. You will then be redirected to the Property Details page.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Record an Other Receipt","This article will walk you through how to record an Other Receipt in Rentvine. This option is typically used to manually record funds being added to a owners ledger outside of a tenant payment.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-record-a-other-receipt","<ul>
<li>On the top of the page, click on the&nbsp
column3: menu button and then click on&nbsp

column2: aria-level=""1"">From the dashboard view of Rentvine, click on the Money In tab under Accounting
>This will be how you increase the funds in an owner's portfolio balance. Here are the following fields you will need to fill out:

column1: • Apply to (Ledger)- This will be the owner's portfolio that you want to refund.
• Received From- This is a field for any information as to why these funds were added to this portfolio.
• Amount Received- This will be the amount that you would like to add to the portfolio ledger.

• Income Account- This is going to be the chart of account you use to record this. Please note that this will need to be an income account. You can create an income account just for this or use a Misc. income account.
• Receipt Date- This will be the date this transaction was actually received.
• Reference- This will be whatever you want to have as the reference associated with this payment.
• Description- This will be used for any other description you would like to add to this payment
• Bank Account- This will allow you to choose the bank account into which this will be deposited.
• Payment Type- This is how you can record how this payment was actually recorded (check, eCheck, cashier's check, etc.).
• Once you are done with this step, you will need to click the save button to record this other payment.

column2: >
Once this is done, you will notice that the portfolio's operating balance will now be increased by this amount.
>

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Create/Add a Unit to a Property.","This article will go over how to add a nunit to a property. ","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-create/add-a-unit-to-a-property","<ul>
<li>Make sure that the property is considered a multi-unit property. You can check this by heading to the property details and looking for the property type.&nbsp
• If the property is set up as a multi-unit property, you should see a “Unit” tab located at the top of the property page, just above the Details section.

• If you do not see the “Unit” tab, it likely means the Multi-Unit toggle was not enabled when the property was originally created. In this case, the property is currently configured as a single-unit property.
If you do not see the ""unit"" tab at the top, please refer to the article attached.
How to Create a Property
2. If the property was created properly and it is considered a multi-unit, then you will want to select the green actions button, and then ""new unit.""
You will also have the option to attach any Files to the unit.
It is important to specify what unit it is, either in the main Address line or the address 2 line.
Once you have filled out all fields, you will click save and that will bring you to the unit details page.

column2: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-07-21%20at%203-46-31%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: Viewing a Newly Created Unit
To view a newly created unit under a property:
Navigate to the Property section.
At the top of the property page, select the “Unit” tab to view all associated units.
If you do not see a ""Unit"" tab, the property may not have been created as a multi-unit property. In that case, you will need to recreate the property with the Multi-Unit option enabled.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Type of Deposits","In Rentvine, deposits play an important role in managing lease agreements, tenant accountability, and property financials. This article will walk you through the different deposit types available in Rentvine. ","en","https://help.rentvine.com/type-of-deposits","<h4 style=""text-align: center
column2: >How to Create a Chart of Accounts and Choose the Deposit Type

column1: When creating a Chart of Account for any type of deposit, it’s important to select “Liability” as the account type. If a different account type is selected, you will not be able to designate the account for deposit tracking.

Once you’ve selected Liability, you’ll see a toggle labeled “Use for Security Deposit Tracking.” Be sure to turn this toggle on — this is what enables the system to treat the account as a deposit-holding account.

After enabling that toggle, a new field will appear called “Deposit Type.” This allows you to specify what type of deposit the account will track (e.g., Security Deposit, Pet Deposit, Cleaning Deposit, etc.).

column2: >

column1: General Deposit – Held to cover potential damage or unpaid rent.
Pet Deposit – Additional deposit for potential pet-related damage.
Cleaning Deposit – Intended to cover professional cleaning after move-out.
Key/Fob Deposit – Covers the cost of lost or unreturned keys or fobs.

column4: >This could be for things not listed.

column2: >

data-start=""157"" data-end=""202"">Now, when creating a Rentsign document, you’ll be able to insert hot fields that automatically populate with the deposit information based on what was entered in the lease. This helps streamline the lease creation process and ensures accuracy without the need for manual entry.
data-start=""157"" data-end=""202"">Why Properly Tracking Deposits Matters
data-start=""204"" data-end=""319"">Accurate tracking of deposits in Rentvine is essential for both financial clarity and legal compliance. Here's why:

column1: Clear Accounting for Owners &
column2:
Tenants
Each deposit represents money that must be held separately and reported correctly.

column1:
Prevents Misuse of Funds
Deposits are liabilities, not income, and must be tracked accordingly. Mixing them with operating income can result in compliance issues and misreporting, which could create problems during audits or owner disputes.

Smooth Move-Out Process
At the end of a lease, knowing exactly which funds are available to apply to damages, unpaid rent, or to refund to the tenant saves time and avoids confusion. Misclassified deposits can lead to delays or errors in issuing refunds.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"How to Record Credit Card Transactions Not Tied to the Trust Bank Account","Do you pay bills within Rentvine using a credit card from your corporate banking account or a bank account other than the trust bank account? This article will walk you through multiple ways of recording said transactions within Rentvine.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/how-to-record-credit-card-transactions-not-tied-to-the-trust-bank-account","<hr>

column2: >Setting the Credit Card as a Bank Account (Managed within Rentvine)
>Setting the Credit Card as a Reimbursement (Managed outside of Rentvine)

><strong>Please note that by following this article, you will be recording corporate accounting within Rentvine. Rentvine is a trust-based accounting system, and its main functions are tailored around trust bank accounts. When recording corporate transactions, it can lead to the comingling of funds, and it is&nbsp
column3: not recommended within the system. By following this article, you are willing to take on this risk, and if needed, you may need to contact an accounting professional as our support team may not be able to help with complications regarding corporate accounting.&nbsp

column1: <li data-stringify-indent=""0"" data-stringify-border=""0"">In a corporate accounting platform, we recommend setting up a GL account called Reimbursable Expenses.
• When the expense is incurred on the credit card, it will be recorded using this GL account
• When the expense is reimbursed from the trust account, it will also be recorded using this GL account, effectively netting the expense to $0 in the corporate accounting platform
Option 2 - Credit Card not tracked in the corporate accounting platform, and used solely for property-related expenses:
<li data-stringify-indent=""0"" data-stringify-border=""0"">Create a vendor in Rentvine called Credit Card

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Pods Feature (In Beta)","This article will go over the new Pods feature within Rentvine and how to best utilize this feature.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/pods-feature","

column2: >How to Create a Pod
>How to Add a User to a Pod

column1: Pods are a powerful new feature in Rentvine that allows you to control what information your users can see. With Pods, you can filter specific users’ views to only the properties, leases, transactions, and work orders assigned within their Pod, nothing more. This is especially useful for larger teams where users need to focus on specific areas without being overwhelmed by unrelated data.
column7: > as a way to
column10: > and then assign users to those groups. Once a user is assigned to a Pod, their access is restricted to only the portfolios in that Pod, ensuring clean, relevant visibility and streamlined workflows tailored to their role.

column1: • For example, without a Pod, users see all units, leases, owners, bills/transactions, and work orders in the system.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Security Measures Every User Should Know","At Rentvine, safeguarding your data and trust account information is a top priority. While we provide enterprise-level security, every user plays a key role.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/simple-security-measures-every-user-should-know","<hr>

column2:
>Why Security Matters

Your Rentvine account contains sensitive information about tenants, owners, and financial transactions. Protecting this data is critical to preventing
unauthorized access and malicious activity.

column1: • Always create a password that is long (12+ characters) and includes a mix of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters.
• Never reuse passwords from other websites. If a different site is compromised, reusing a password puts your Rentvine account at risk.
• Avoid easy-to-guess information (names, birthdays, pets, or simple words).
• Please note that the maximum amount of characters Rentvine allows for passwords is currently 35 characters.
• To enhance the security of your Rentvine account, we strongly encourage you to enable Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) on the email account associated with your Rentvine username.
• Even if your password were compromised, this additional security step makes it far more difficult for someone else to get into your account.
<li>To get started, here are helpful direct MFA links for the&nbsp
• Enable 2-Step Verification on Google (Gmail)
• Set Up Two-Step Verification on Microsoft/Outlook
• If you use a different email provider, please refer to their support documentation for instructions.
If you receive an MFA code you did not request, do not enter it. This may indicate someone else is trying to access your account.
• If you ever suspect unusual activity (unexpected MFA codes, logins you don’t recognize, or suspicious emails), contact Rentvine Support immediately.
• Prompt reporting allows us to secure your account and prevent potential data breaches.
Always confirm it’s you initiating the login or payment before using an MFA code.
Your Rentvine account is only as secure as the device you access it from.
Install regular updates for your computer, tablet, or smartphone.
Use antivirus and anti-malware software.
Lock your screen when stepping away from your device.
Avoid using public Wi-Fi without a secure VPN.
• Do not download or install software from unverified or unrelated sources. Random downloads can contain malware that exposes sensitive data.
Cybercriminals often try to trick users into giving away login credentials. Always be cautious of unexpected messages.
Do not click on suspicious links in emails or texts claiming to be from Rentvine.

column2: ask for your password by email or text.

column1: Verify sender details before opening attachments.
If you ever receive a questionable message, contact Rentvine Support directly instead of replying or clicking.
<li data-stringify-indent=""0"" data-stringify-border=""0"">When in doubt, log in directly to&nbsp

column2: >Can I keep working in a Stale Tab without refreshing?

column1: • Yes, you can continue to view the data on the current page you are on, but the next navigation or Pod change will refresh the tab.
• Yes, any unsaved entries may be cleared by a refresh. We recommend submitting the changes or copying them first.
• Can we have two tabs on the same Pod?
• Yes, if both tabs are already on the same Active Pod, you won't be forced to refresh when navigating through the software.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Rentsign Settings","Would you like to customize the Rentsign notifications and expiration dates on Rentsign documents? This article will walk you through customizing those settings at the global and individual document level. ","en","https://help.rentvine.com/new-rentsign-enhancements","<hr>
• Go to your global settings by selecting your initials in the top right corner of your screen.

column6:
src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/undefined.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
Default Days Until Document Expires

column1: The Default Days Until Document Expires setting determines how long a Rentsign document remains valid for signature after it has been sent.
Default value: 120 days
Range: Minimum of 1 day, maximum of 255 days
Format: This field is based on numerical days

This setting can be adjusted to fit your organization’s needs. For example, if you set the expiration period to 60 days, the document will automatically expire 60 days after it was sent out for signature.

column2: Important: Once a document expires, it can no longer be signed. A new version must be generated and sent for signature.

column1: The Default Days Until Starting Reminders setting controls when the first reminder is sent to a pending signer who has not yet signed a document.
Default value: 1 day
Range: Minimum of 1 day, maximum of 255 days
Format: This field is based on numerical days

This setting can be adjusted to match your organization’s workflow. For example, if you set the value to 6 days, the first reminder will be sent exactly 6 days after the document was issued and remains unsigned.
Important: This setting only determines when the first reminder is sent. Additional reminder settings may further control follow-up notifications.
The Default Reminder Frequency in Days setting determines how often reminders are sent to a pending signer after
Range: Minimum of 1 day, maximum of 255 days
Format: This field is based on numerical days
It’s important to note that this setting only takes effect after the Default Days Until Starting Reminders period has passed. In other words, the starting reminder setting always takes precedence.
For example, if this field is set to 5 days, reminders will continue to be sent to the signer every 5 days after the first reminder, until the document is signed or expires.
Important: This setting controls the frequency of reminders, not the start time. Always configure it in tandem with your starting reminder settings for best results.

column2: >Default Days Before Expiration to Start Expiration Notice

column1: The Default Days Before Expiration to Start Expiration Notice setting controls when the system stops sending standard signer reminders and begins sending urgent “About to Expire” notices. These notices use stronger, time-sensitive messaging directed at the recipient.
Default value: 3 days
Range: Minimum of 1 day, maximum of 255 days
Format: This field is based on numerical days

For example, if the Default Days Until Document Expires is set to 200 days and the Default Days Before Expiration to Start Expiration Notice is set to 20, the system will switch from regular reminders to expiration notices once the document reaches 180 days unsigned.
Important: This setting applies specifically to expiration notices, not standard signing reminders.
<li>To view the settings within an individual document,&nbsp
column2: you will create the document as normal and add all necessary information.&nbsp

column1: <li>When sending out the document, you will be prompted with multiple items under the ""Expiration Settings"" and ""Reminder Settings"". The individual settings are listed below:

column2: Will be the date the document as a whole expires, and will no longer allow signable parties to complete the signature process.

Q: Does the explicit Expiration Date always win over the “days until” default?
 A: Yes. If you set a specific date, RentSign uses that date as the backstop.

column1: Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Maintenance Work Order History","This article goes over the Work Order History and best practices to maneuver this feature within Rentvine.","en","https://help.rentvine.com/maintenance-work-order-history","<ul>

The new Rentvine Maintenance History feature allows you to view the full history of work orders for a property. This is separate from active work orders, making it much easier to search and track past activity.
You can access Maintenance History on any property under the Maintenance tab.

column2: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%202-12-10%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">
column3: src=""https://9252921.fs1.hubspotusercontent-na1.net/hubfs/9252921/Screenshot%202025-09-30%20at%202-12-26%E2%80%AFPM-png.png"" width=""688"" loading=""lazy"">

column1: If the property is set up as a multi-unit, you’ll see all work orders tied to its units directly at the property level. This means you don’t need to click into each individual unit to find related work orders.
Of course, you can still go to the specific unit if you’d like to view work orders for just that unit.
You can also access this page directly from a work order. Simply select View Property History, located at the top right of the work order screen.
• Number - This will be a direct hyperlink to direct you to the actual work order
• Technician - This is the vendor or internal maintenance tech assigned to the work order
• Status - This is the status of the work order
• Unit - This is the specific unit the work order is tied to. If you see ' - - ', this means the work order is not assigned specifically to a unit, but the whole property itself

column2: >- This is the Priority severity of the work order

column1: • Description - This gives the work order description

column2: shows the user assigned to the work order

column1: • Due Date (not on Past Lease) - This shows the entered Due Date for the work order

column2: This will show the entered Scheduled Start Date of the work order

column1: • Scheduled Maintenance Window (not on Past Lease) - This will show the agreed upon Scheduled Maintenance Window for the work order
• Amount Billed (not on Past Lease) - This shows the Amount billed for the work order
• Amount Paid (not on Past Lease) - This shows the Amount that has been paid currently
• Maintenance Category (on Past Lease) - This shows the Maintenance Category tied to the work order

column2: (on Past Lease) - This shows the location
column3: of where the work order is located

column1: • Issue / Resolution Photos (on Past Lease)- These are clickable icons
column2: to show either the Issue Photos or the Resolution Photos
This will show all work orders tied to the property, regardless of the status
This will only show work orders attached to an active lease
This will only show work orders attached to the property or unit specifically, and not leases
This will show all work orders attached to a Closed Lease
This will show all Recurring Work Orders currently set up for the specific property

column1: With Maintenance History, you have a complete record of everything that’s happened at a property, all in one place. Whether the work order was tied to an active lease, created for a make-ready, or set up as a recurring task, it’s now easy to find and review.
Look back at past work to see what’s already been completed.
Verify details like who handled the job, when it was done, and what was billed or paid.
Keep owners and tenants informed with accurate history on repairs and maintenance.
Save time by not having to jump between units or search through multiple screens.

By keeping all of this organized and accessible, Maintenance History helps you stay on top of property care and ensures nothing slips through the cracks.

Rentvine Knowledge Base,"Introduction to Tenant Statements","How to Generate and Format Tenant Statements with Financial and Maintenance Breakdowns","en","https://help.rentvine.com/introduction-to-tenant-statements","<hr>
Within this article, you will learn how to generate tenant statements, format these statements with our new Tenant Statement Settings, and publish these statements for your tenants.
Tenant statements can be formatted as you want using the new Tenant Statement Settings.

column3: Tenant Statement Settings

column1: Once in the setting page you can either select your current Tenant Statement or you can create a new statement setting.
<li>When in the Statement Setting, there are three main categories you can adjust.
Summary - Give a summary of the tenant's financials for the statement period
Ledger -Give a breakdown of all increases and decreases to the tenant's lease ledger
Work Orders - Reflect any work orders that occurred during the statement period

• To adjust the tenant statement, whether that is removing the page breaks or removing the summary, ledger, or work order section, you will want to select the ellipses at the top right of the page and select the edit option. You can also duplicate this statement setting or delete it from the setting page
<li>In Rentvine, you can run Tenant Statements in two different ways.
To generate multiple tenant statements within a batch, as well as publish these statements to your tenants' portals for viewing, you will want to follow this workflow.

• First, you will want to go to the leases page in Rentvine, where you will see the statement batches selection. In this page, you will be able to generate these tenant statement batches, as well as view previously generated batches for your tenants.
<li>Once in the Statement Batch, you will have a few different settings to choose from to format this for your tenants.

• Send From Last Statement – If you want all tenant statements to have uniform start and end dates, keep this toggle off. If instead you’d like the start date on tenant statements to be based on the end date of the tenant’s most recent statement, turn this toggle on.

The Start Date and End Date will automatically fill based on the Accounting start date from your settings. You can override these dates, or use the quick-select buttons under the date fields to change the period or year. The dates you choose will determine the reporting period for the tenant statement.

• The Auto Publish toggle will be off by default. If you leave it off, you’ll have another step to send/publish the tenant statements after you create them. This gives you time to review them before sending. If you switch Auto Publish on, the tenant statements will be sent/published immediately after you click the green Create button.
• The Send Notifications toggle will be on by default. If you don’t want tenants to receive a notification email when statements are published, you can turn this off.

• The Override Statement Setting toggle will also be off by default. Leaving this off means each tenant statement will use the statement setting already assigned to each tenant. If you turn it on, you can choose a different tenant statement setting that will apply to all tenant statements being sent/published.
Finally, you’ll see a Statement Message field. Here you can add a message that will appear on each tenant statement. You can include hotfields, and if you’d like, you can also use Snippets.
Click Next to continue.

Once Generated, you can view all previously generated statements within the lease in the statements section. From there you have the option to download these to your device, or delete if the statement is invalid or no longer needed.
If you are wanting to generate individual Tenant
column2: statements for your management company bookkeeping, you will want to follow this workflow.

column1: • First you will want to identify the lease that you are wanting to generate the statement for.
<li>When in the lease page to generate a tenant statement, you will want to go to the <strong>Green Actions&gt
column2: New Statement

column1: • From that page you will want to select the statement setting as well as the time period you want to generate for your tenant and then select Save.
<li>Once you select save, your device will take some time to generate the statement preview for you, and will be broken down into three separate sections.
• Resident Statement-Overview of finances tied to the lease
• Transactions- Full breakdown of all related charges and payments to the tenant within the selected statement period

column2: See all associated work orders started/completed within the statement period
